description: Remarks (via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Council on Foreign Relations, 14 January 2022.

author: John C Williams
title: Business more like usual
Key quote: Assuming the economy continues to improve as I anticipate, a moderation in the pace of asset purchases may soon be warranted.
Rationale: The speaker indicates that despite some signs of inflation, expectations are well anchored, and it's anticipated to decline which suggests a continued accommodative stance. The mention of substantial progress towards inflation goals but a long way to maximum employment indicates a preference to maintain current policy, likely suggesting a hold on rate changes.
description: Remarks (via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Economic Club of New York, 27 September 2021.

author: John C Williams
title: Ever upward
Key quote: Assuming the economy continues to improve as I anticipate, it could be appropriate to start reducing the pace of asset purchases this year.
Rationale: Williams acknowledges that substantial progress has been made toward the inflation goal and that it may soon be time to reduce asset purchases, which is an indication of a shift towards tightening monetary policy. However, he also notes the need for further improvement towards maximum employment, suggesting a balanced approach.
description: Remarks (via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at St. Lawrence University, 8 September 2021.

author: John C Williams
title: The theory of average inflation targeting
Key quote: Importantly, the versions of AIT that I described represent an evolution of inflation targeting, rather than a revolution.
Rationale: The speech is primarily an academic discussion of average inflation targeting (AIT) strategies without making any commitments to immediate policy changes. The emphasis on AIT as an evolution rather than a revolution suggests a balanced approach to policy, anticipating holding the current rate given prevailing low neutral rates and acknowledging the lower bound constraints.
description: Remarks (via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Bank of Israel/CEPR Conference on "Inflation: Dynamics, Expectations, and Targeting", 12 July 2021.

author: John C Williams
title: Good day sunshine
Key quote: The data and conditions have not progressed enough for the FOMC to shift its monetary policy stance of strong support for the economic recovery.
Rationale: Williams expresses optimism about the economy's recovery but emphasizes the need to maintain supportive monetary policy conditions. The outlook on inflation suggests that he sees current spikes as temporary, which aligns with a somewhat dovish stance, indicating no immediate rate hikes.
description: Remarks (via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Midsize Bank Coalition of America, 21 June 2021.

author: John C Williams
title: The economic recovery - are we there yet?
Key quote: Although we still have a long road ahead of us to achieve a robust and full recovery, with strong support from monetary policy, I am confident we will reach our destination.
Rationale: John C. Williams emphasizes the need for continued strong monetary support due to the economic recovery not yet reaching maximum employment and stable inflation goals. His remarks support the continuation of low interest rates, suggesting dovish leanings with a likely decision to hold rates steady.
description: Remarks (via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Women in Housing and Finance 2021 Annual Symposium, 4 May 2021.

author: John C Williams
title: The economic outlook- getting back to "more like normal"
Key quote: Despite uncertainties, we are fully committed to supporting the economy through this period and reaching our maximum employment and price stability goals.
Rationale: Williams highlights the Fed's commitment to maintaining low interest rates until economic recovery is more certain with maximum employment and inflation targets being met. This suggests a focus on economic support and a dovish stance.
description: Remarks (via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at One Hundred Black Men of New York, 25 February 2021.

author: John C Williams
title: The longer-run framework - a look ahead
Key quote: In terms of monetary policy, the appropriate focus right now is on getting the country back to work. For that reason, policy is supporting very low interest rates to provide stimulus to the economic recovery and keeping inflation expectations anchored at 2 percent.
Rationale: Williams emphasizes the need for lower interest rates to aid economic recovery following the pandemic without mentioning any immediate tightening. The intent to address employment shortfalls and allow for periods of inflation running above 2% indicates a dovish stance, but acknowledging the trappings of the lower bound suggests a neutral bias towards holding rates as the situation unfolds.
description: Remarks (via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Hoover Institution Monetary Policy Virtual Series: The Road Ahead for Central Banks, 7 October 2020.

author: John C Williams
title: A solution to every puzzle
Key quote: The events of the past year have demonstrated the critical role central banks can and must play in extraordinary times when market stress and dysfunction threaten to spill over into the economy.
Rationale: Williams highlights the Fed's significant interventions to support market functioning and assures their effectiveness in preventing severe economic setbacks. His emphasis on maintaining low rates supports a somewhat dovish stance, likely indicating a preference to 'Hold' the current policy rate to sustain recovery.
description: Remarks (via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the 2020 US Treasury Market Conference, 29 September 2020.

author: John C Williams
title: A new chapter for the FOMC monetary policy framework
Key quote: The new framework statement directly and effectively addresses the problems caused by a low neutral rate and persistently low inflation.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes a framework adjustment that suggests monetary policy tolerance for temporary inflation overshooting to address consistently below-target inflation. This reflects a somewhat dovish stance, indicating no immediate urgency to raise rates, and aligns with maintaining the current low policy rate to support economic recovery and employment.
description: Remarks (via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the "In Conversation: New York Fed Presidents on COVID-19" Bretton Woods Committee Webinar, 2 September 2020.

author: John C Williams
title: Rising to the challenge - central banking, financial markets, and the pandemic
Key quote: In the first half of March, as the pandemic began to unfold in the U.S., the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) lowered the federal funds rate effectively to zero.
Rationale: The speech discusses the extensive measures taken by the Federal Reserve to provide liquidity and support the economy during the pandemic, emphasizing a continuation of low rates and expansive monetary policy to counteract economic disruption. The likelihood of a rate cut is low given rates are already near zero, suggesting holding the current policy rate is the probable action.
description: Remarks (via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the 16th Meeting of the Financial Research Advisory Committee for the Treasury's Office of Financial Research, 16 July 2020.

author: John C Williams
title: A different kind of recession
Key quote: The FOMC has indicated that it expects to keep interest rates at this level until it is confident that the economy has weathered recent events and is on track to achieve its maximum employment and price stability goals.
Rationale: Given the severe economic downturn and uncertainty due to the pandemic, the speech emphasizes continued low interest rates and substantial Fed interventions to stabilize the economy, exhibiting a dovish stance. While acknowledging some signs of recovery, the focus remains on supporting the economy, making a rate cut unlikely but a hold very probable.
description: Remarks (via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Institute of International Finance: Central Banking in the Age of COVID-19 Summit, 30 June 2020.

author: John C Williams
title: The economy in the time of coronavirus
Key quote: The FOMC has indicated that it expects to keep interest rates at this level until it is confident that the economy has weathered recent events and is on track to achieve its maximum employment and price stability goals.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the severe economic challenges posed by the pandemic, the uncertainty of the recovery, and the aggressive monetary policy actions already taken to support the economy. The Fed's near-zero interest rate and the expectation to maintain it suggest a highly dovish position with little indication towards tightening policy at the next meeting.
description: Remarks (via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Buffalo Niagara Partnership, the Greater Rochester Chamber of Commerce, and CenterState CEO, 21 May 2020.

author: John C Williams
title: A time for bold action
Key quote: The Federal Reserve took swift and decisive action to support the economy and stabilize financial markets.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for bold actions to support the economy and stabilize financial markets amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, reinforcing the stance of maintaining low interest rates to facilitate recovery, which aligns with a dovish position. However, given the severity of the pandemic impact, the likelihood of rate cutting further is low, leading to a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Remarks (delivered via videoconference) by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Economic Club of New York, New York City, 16 April 2020.

author: John C Williams
title: Research, policy, and the zero lower bound
Key quote: He developed and analyzed what were then considered 'outside the box' options for overcoming the ZLB.
Rationale: Williams discusses unconventional tools for addressing the zero lower bound and highlights past advocacy for innovative measures like negative interest rates and asset purchases, suggesting openness to easing policy further if needed.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Shadow Open Market Committee Spring Meeting, New York City, 6 March 2020.

author: John C Williams
title: The economic outlook
Key quote: Earlier this week, the FOMC voted unanimously to lower the target range for the federal funds rate to 1 to 1-1/4 percent.
Rationale: Williams highlights the risks posed by the coronavirus to the economy and the unanimous decision of the FOMC to cut rates, indicating a dovish stance with a willingness to further cut rates if necessary to support the economy.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Foreign Policy Association, New York City, 5 March 2020.

author: John C Williams
title: Inflation targeting - securing the anchor
Key quote: One key takeaway from these global trends is that interest rates and inflation are going to stay lower than we've come to expect in the past.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the challenges of low inflation and the lower neutral rate of interest, suggesting a cautious and accommodative approach to monetary policy while acknowledging the structural factors keeping rates low.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Bank of England Research Workshop on "The Future of Inflation Targeting", London, 9 January 2020.

author: John C Williams
title: No man is an island
Key quote: The adjustments to monetary policy we made this year were designed to balance maintaining a strong U.S. economy with slowing global growth, and provide insurance against ongoing and potential future risks.
Rationale: Williams highlights that the recent policy adjustments are aimed at maintaining balance amid current economic conditions and uncertainties, suggesting a cautious approach to monetary policy without indicating a clear direction towards further rate cuts or hikes.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the 2019 Asia Economic Policy Conference, Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, San Francisco, California, 14 November 2019.

author: John C Williams
title: Money markets and the federal funds rate - the path forward
Key quote: I should emphasize that all of these actions are aimed at the implementation of monetary policy and do not in any way represent a change in the stance of monetary policy.
Rationale: The speech is technical, focusing on the mechanics of financial markets, particularly regarding the ample reserves framework and repo market operations, without indicating any change in monetary policy stance. This suggests a neutral tone, leaning towards holding interest rates steady.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Outlook 2019, New York City, 17 October 2019.

author: John C Williams
title: Monetary policy and the economic outlook
Key quote: Low inflation is indeed the problem of this era.
Rationale: Williams emphasizes persistently low inflation, uncertainties, and slowing global growth, suggesting a more accommodative stance to support continued growth and employment. This indicates a likelihood towards cutting rates to address these challenges.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at Euromoney Real Return XIII: The Inflation-Linked Products Conference 2019, New York City, 4 September 2019.

author: John C Williams
title: Living life near the ZLB
Key quote: First, take swift action when faced with adverse economic conditions. Second, keep interest rates lower for longer.
Rationale: John C Williams emphasizes the importance of moving quickly to add stimulus at the ZLB, maintaining lower rates for longer, and adapting strategies for a low r-star environment, indicating a preference for an accommodative policy stance.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the 2019 Annual Meeting of the Central Bank Research Association (CEBRA), New York City, 18 July 2019.

author: John C Williams
title: A tale of many economies
Key quote: Finally, turning to prices, the latest data show that underlying inflation is 1.6 percent, below our 2 percent goal.
Rationale: The speech indicates concern about inflation being below the Fed's target and its potential negative impact on inflation expectations. This suggests a dovish inclination to lower rates to stimulate the economy and address the below-target inflation.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at University at Albany-SUNY, Albany, New York, 11 July 2019.

author: John C Williams
title: If we fail to prepare, we prepare to fail
Key quote: Inflation that's too low is now a more pressing problem.
Rationale: Williams emphasizes the challenges of persistently low inflation and suggests reconsidering monetary policy strategies, which indicate a dovish stance. He also highlights the limited room for maneuvering interest rates, suggesting a potential rate cut to address low inflation concerns.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Council on Foreign Relations, New York City, 6 June 2019.

author: John C Williams
title: The research-policy nexus - ZLB, JMCB and FOMC
Key quote: One lesson was that short-term rates should be cut aggressively when deflation or a severe downturn threatens. That is, do not 'keep your powder dry.'
Rationale: The speech emphasizes lessons learned for handling the zero lower bound, including cutting rates aggressively when needed. However, there is no immediate indication of action, resulting in a 'Hold' prediction, but with a dovish lean given the focus on aggressive rate cuts and maintaining lower rates.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Conference celebrating the 50th Anniversary of the "Journal of Money, Credit and Banking", Federal Reserve Bank of New York, New York City, 31 May 2019.

author: John C Williams
title: When the facts change...
Key quote: Policymakers around the globe need to prepare for the challenges of navigating the new realities of slow global growth and low r-star.
Rationale: The speech discusses the persistent challenges of low inflation and low neutral interest rates, suggesting a need for new approaches in monetary policy without explicitly advocating for immediate rate changes.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the 9th High-Level Conference on the International Monetary System, Zürich, 14 May 2019.

author: John C Williams
title: The joys of spring
Key quote: The economy remains on a path of healthy growth, with a very strong labor market and without the emergence of inflationary pressures.
Rationale: John C. Williams highlights strong economic performance but also points out low inflation pressures and expresses a continued patient approach, making it somewhat dovish. The emphasis on maintaining the current policy setting suggests a 'Hold' decision is likely at the next meeting.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the 21st Annual Bronx Bankers Breakfast, Bronx, New York, 10 May 2019.

author: John C Williams
title: The "new normal" for growth
Key quote: With the economy running close to our dual mandate goals, monetary policy is in the right place.
Rationale: Williams suggests that the economy is currently balanced regarding inflation and employment, indicating that current interest rates are appropriate. This suggests a neutral stance with no immediate need to adjust rates.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the Community Bankers Conference, hosted by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, New York City, 4 April 2019.

author: John C Williams
title: The economic outlook - the "new normal" is now
Key quote: The FOMC decided to keep interest rates where they were at the most recent meeting, and noted the importance of patience in determining future policy actions.
Rationale: John C. Williams emphasizes a 'data dependent' approach, signifying a neutral stance given the current conditions where the economy is at a neutral interest rate. His balanced view on risks and current economic alignment with r-star suggests holding rates is the most likely decision.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at The Economic Club of New York, New York City, 6 March 2019.

author: John C Williams
title: Discussion of "Prospects for Inflation in a High Pressure Economy: Is the Phillips Curve Dead or Is It Just Hibernating?" by Peter Hooper, Frederic S. Mishkin, and Amir Sufi
Key quote: In summary, the Phillips curve is alive and well. I wholeheartedly agree with the authors that we must not be complacent about inflation expectations becoming unmoored, whether at too high or too low a level.
Rationale: John C. Williams emphasizes the importance of not being complacent about inflation expectations, suggesting a concern for potential inflationary pressures due to tight labor markets. However, he also highlights the importance of maintaining the inflation expectations anchor, which points to a balanced approach without immediate intention to raise rates, thus the 'Hold' prediction.
description: Remarks by Mr John C Williams, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at the US Monetary Policy Forum, New York City, 22 February 2019.

author: Adriana D Kugler
title: The challenges facing economic measurement and creative solutions
Key quote: I anticipate that it will be appropriate to begin easing monetary policy later this year.
Rationale: Ms. Kugler expresses openness to easing monetary policy if disinflation continues and acknowledges balance in risks to inflation and employment, indicating a cautious optimism and somewhat dovish view towards future monetary policy.
description: Speech by Ms Adriana D Kugler, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the 21st Annual Economic Measurement Seminar, organised by the National Association for Business Economics Foundation, Washington DC, 16 July 2024.

author: Adriana D Kugler
title: Some reasons for optimism about inflation
Key quote: If the economy evolves as I am expecting, it will likely become appropriate to begin easing policy sometime later this year.
Rationale: The speech expresses optimism about inflation coming down and suggests that current monetary policy is restrictive enough. The speaker indicates that policy easing might be appropriate later in the year if trends continue as expected, which signals a somewhat dovish stance.
description: Speech by Ms Adriana D Kugler, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, Washington DC, 18 June 2024.

author: Adriana D Kugler
title: The outlook for the US economy and monetary policy
Key quote: Most FOMC participants expect that it will be appropriate to begin lowering the federal funds rate sometime this year.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the progress made in reducing inflation and reflects an expectation of continued disinflation, suggesting a somewhat dovish stance. While there is acknowledgment of uncertainties, the overall tone indicates comfort with current policy settings, implying a decision to hold rates.
description: Speech by Ms Adriana D Kugler, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Weidenbaum Center on the Economy, Government, and Public Policy, Washington University in St. Louis, St. Louis, Missouri, 3 April 2024.

author: Adriana D Kugler
title: Disinflation without a rise in unemployment? What is different this time around
Key quote: For the reasons I have been discussing, I am cautiously optimistic that we will see continued progress on disinflation without significant deterioration of the labor market.
Rationale: The speech addresses the potential tradeoffs between inflation and unemployment but concludes with an optimistic outlook on achieving disinflation without rising unemployment, suggesting a balanced view rather than advocating for immediate policy changes. The emphasis on optimism without significant deterioration in the labor market implies that the speaker might prefer maintaining the current policy rate for now.
description: Speech by Ms Adriana D Kugler, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the 2024 Stanford Institute for Economic Policy Research Economic Summit, Stanford University, Stanford, California, 1 March 2024.

author: Adriana D Kugler
title: The outlook for the economy and monetary policy
Key quote: For now, I see the risks to our dual mandate as roughly balanced; our policy stance is restrictive, but the target range for the federal funds rate has been steady for some time now, and the most recent Summary of Economic Projections by FOMC participants suggests that the rate is at its peak level, if the economy evolves as expected.
Rationale: The speech reflects a neutral stance with balanced acknowledgment of the dual mandate: inflation has been slowing down but there are still risks. Adriana D. Kugler mentions the possibility of holding the rate steady if progress occurs as expected, which suggests a 'Hold' with a relatively high probability.
description: Speech by Ms Adriana D Kugler, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Brookings Institution, Washington DC, 7 February 2024.

author: Lisa D Cook
title: Common inflation and monetary policy challenges across countries
Key quote: For all central banks, the question is how best to ensure continued disinflation while avoiding unnecessary damage to the economy.
Rationale: Lisa D. Cook highlights the recent decrease in global components of inflation, predicts a continuation of the disinflation process, and expresses optimism about achieving a 'soft landing.' Her discussion of considering whether to further raise rates suggests a somewhat dovish stance, but she acknowledges the need to be ready to adjust policies, reflecting a cautious approach leaning towards holding rates.
description: Speech by Ms Lisa D Cook, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Australian Conference of Economists 2024, Adelaide, Australia, 10 July 2024.

author: Lisa D Cook
title: The dual mandate and the balance of risks
Key quote: The risks to achieving our employment and inflation goals are moving into better balance.
Rationale: The speech highlights improvements in inflation and employment, suggesting a balanced risk approach. Although it mentions the need for careful easing, it does not advocate for immediate rate cuts, indicating a 'hold' stance.
description: Remarks by Ms Lisa D Cook, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Ec10b Principles of Economics Lecture, Department of Economics, Faculty of Arts and Sciences, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, 25 March 2024.

author: Lisa D Cook
title: Sources of uncertainty in the short run and the long run
Key quote: I would like to have greater confidence that inflation is converging to 2 percent before beginning to cut the policy rate.
Rationale: Cook emphasizes the recent disinflation and suggests monitoring the economy closely before considering policy adjustments. Although she acknowledges the restrictive nature of current policy, her caution indicates she would likely vote to hold rates steady to ensure inflation continues to decline.
description: Speech by Ms Lisa D Cook, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the "Macrofinance in the Long Run: New Insights on the Global Economy" 2024 Annual Conference of the Julis-Rabinowitz Center for Public Policy & Finance at Princeton's School of Public and International Affairs, Princeton, New Jersey, 22 February 2024.

author: Lisa D Cook
title: Global linkages - supply, spillovers, and common challenge
Key quote: I see risks as two sided, requiring us to balance the risk of not tightening enough against the risk of tightening too much.
Rationale: The speaker acknowledges progress in disinflation and improving labor market conditions while emphasizing the need to balance risks of under-tightening and over-tightening. The speech does not lean strongly towards further tightening or loosening, suggesting a neutral stance likely resulting in holding the current rate.
description: Speech by Ms Lisa D Cook, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at "Global Linkages in a Post-Pandemic World" 2023 Asia Economic Policy Conference, sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco Center for Pacific Basin Studies, San Francisco, California, 16 November 2023.

author: Lisa D Cook
title: Financial stability - resilience and challenges
Key quote: Achieving the Federal Reserve's dual mandate of maximum employment and stable prices depends on a stable financial system.
Rationale: The speech mainly focuses on financial stability and stability risks, with no explicit emphasis on changing monetary policy direction. The risks discussed are observed, but the overall stability and resilience suggest a balanced stance concerning immediate rate adjustments.
description: Speech by Ms Lisa D Cook, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at Duke University, Durham, North Carolina, 6 November 2023.

author: Lisa D Cook
title: The US economic outlook and monetary policy
Key quote: If data show continued strength in the economy and slower disinflation, we may have more work to do.
Rationale: Governor Cook acknowledges mixed signals in the economy, with a strong job market but persistent inflation, leading her to favor a cautious approach. She supports ongoing monitoring and potentially more tightening, but the speech suggests current conditions are likely to warrant holding rates steady to assess impacts.
description: Speech by Ms Lisa D Cook, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the 2023 Midwest Economics Association 87th Annual Meeting, Cleveland, Ohio, 31 March 2023.

author: Lisa D Cook
title: Thoughts on inflation in a supply-constrained economy
Key quote: Inflation remains far too high, despite some encouraging signs lately, and is therefore of great concern.
Rationale: Lisa D. Cook expressed concern about persistently high inflation and emphasized the commitment to returning inflation to the 2% target. Despite some moderating signs, her focus on the need to control inflation and the potential for supply chain disruptions suggest a leaning towards raising rates to curb inflationary pressures.
description: Speech by Ms Lisa D Cook, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the 2023 Allied Social Science Associations (ASSA) Annual Meeting, New Orleans, Louisiana, 6 January 2023.

author: Lisa D Cook
title: The economic outlook and US productivity
Key quote: Altogether, inflation is still unacceptably high and must be our primary focus.
Rationale: Despite acknowledging improvements in some areas, the speech makes it clear that inflation remains too high and that further rate increases will be necessary, emphasizing a hawkish stance.
description: Speech by Ms Lisa D Cook, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Detroit Economic Club, Detroit, Michigan, 30 November 2022.

author: Lisa D Cook
title: Economic outlook
Key quote: In sum, inflation is too high, it must come down, and we will keep at it until the job is done.
Rationale: The speech clearly indicates a strong focus on bringing inflation down, with an acknowledgment that inflation is unacceptably high, persistent, and must be addressed. The call for ongoing rate hikes and maintaining restrictive policy for a while showcases a resolute and hawkish stance.
description: Speech by Ms Lisa D Cook, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, Washington DC, 6 October 2022.

author: Michelle W Bowman
title: Recent views on monetary policy and the economic outlook
Key quote: I preferred a smaller initial cut in the policy rate while the U.S. economy remains strong and inflation remains a concern, despite recent progress.
Rationale: Bowman expresses concern about high core inflation and indicates a preference for a more measured approach to rate cuts, suggesting a cautious stance that leans toward maintaining a restrictive policy for now.
description: Speech by Ms Michelle W Bowman, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the 2024 Kentucky Bankers Association Annual Convention, Hot Springs, Virginia, 24 September 2024.

author: Michelle W Bowman
title: Remarks on the economic outlook and financial inclusion
Key quote: Should the incoming data continue to show that inflation is moving sustainably toward our 2 percent goal, it will become appropriate to gradually lower the federal funds rate to prevent monetary policy from becoming overly restrictive on economic activity and employment.
Rationale: The speech reflects cautious optimism about inflation trends, acknowledging progress but noting that inflation is still above target. The emphasis on monitoring data and the potential for holding rates indicates a somewhat hawkish stance, given the readiness to prevent overly restrictive policy.
description: Remarks by Ms Michelle W Bowman, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Alaska Bankers Association, Anchorage, Alaska, 20 August 2024.

author: Michelle W Bowman
title: Update on the economic outlook, and perspective on bank culture, M&A, and liquidity
Key quote: I continue to view inflation as somewhat elevated. And with some upside risks to inflation, I still see the need to pay close attention to the price-stability side of our mandate.
Rationale: Michelle Bowman acknowledges the progress made in reducing inflation but expresses concerns about its sustainability and points out upside risks. Her emphasis on remaining cautious suggests a tendency towards hawkishness, but her baseline outlook indicates that if inflation data continue to improve, lowering rates might be considered in the future. Thus, she would likely vote to hold rates in the upcoming meeting while closely monitoring further data.
description: Speech by Ms Michelle W Bowman, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the 2024 CEO and Senior Management Summit and Annual Meeting, sponsored by the Kansas Bankers Association, Colorado Springs, Colorado, 10 August 2024.

author: Michelle W Bowman
title: Brief remarks on the economy, monetary policy and bank regulation
Key quote: While the current stance of monetary policy appears to be at a restrictive level, I remain willing to raise the target range for the federal funds rate at a future meeting should the incoming data indicate that progress on inflation has stalled or reversed.
Rationale: Bowman acknowledges progress on inflation but emphasizes remaining risks and the need to potentially raise rates if inflation does not decline as expected.
description: Speech by Ms Michelle W Bowman, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Idaho, Nevada, Oregon and Washington Bankers Associations 2024 Annual Convention, Stevenson, Washington DC, 27 June 2024.

author: Michelle W Bowman
title: The consequences of bank capital reform
Key quote: While the current stance of monetary policy appears to be at a restrictive level, I remain willing to raise the target range for the federal funds rate at a future meeting should the incoming data indicate that progress on inflation has stalled or reversed.
Rationale: The emphasis on upside risks to inflation and concerns about potential re-acceleration of inflation point towards a somewhat hawkish stance, though she acknowledges the current restrictive policy and does not advocate an immediate rate hike. The likelihood of holding interest rates steady seems high given her caution and reliance on incoming data.
description: Speech by Ms Michelle W Bowman, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the International Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA)  Board of Directors, London, England, 26 June 2024.

title: Testimony at nomination hearing
Key quote: Our monetary policy is focused on getting inflation back down to 2 percent while sustaining a recovery that includes everyone.
Rationale: The speech highlights concerns about high inflation and emphasizes the task of bringing it back to 2 percent, indicating a somehwat hawkish stance. The focus on continued recovery also suggests caution, balancing inflation control and support for economic growth.
description: Speech by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, before the US Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs, Washington DC, 13 January 2022.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Navigating Delta headwinds on the path to a full recovery
Key quote: The forward guidance on maximum employment and average inflation sets a much higher bar for the liftoff of the policy rate than for slowing the pace of asset purchases.
Rationale: Brainard highlights the downside risks posed by the Delta variant and stresses the uncertainty in the economic outlook, indicating a preference for cautiousness. She acknowledges the high inflation but attributes it to COVID-related disruptions, suggesting it is transitory. This suggests a somewhat dovish stance with likely support for holding rates.
description: Speech by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at "Shocks, Shifts, and the Emerging Economic Landscape" 2021 Annual Meeting of the National Association for Business Economics, Arlington, Virginia, 27 September 2021.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Assessing progress as the economy moves from reopening to recovery
Key quote: The determination of when to begin to slow asset purchases will depend importantly on the accumulation of evidence that substantial further progress on employment has been achieved.
Rationale: The speech reflects concerns about continued labor market slack and transitory inflation pressures. There is recognition of progress but emphasis on ongoing employment shortfalls and the need to be vigilant on inflation expectations. This suggests a cautionary approach, leading to a more dovish stance overall.
description: Speech by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at "Rebuilding the Post-Pandemic Economy" 2021 Annual Meeting of the Aspen Economic Strategy Group, Aspen, Colorado, 30 July 2021

author: Lael Brainard
title: Remaining steady as the economy reopens
Key quote: The best way to achieve our maximum-employment and average-inflation goals is to be steady and transparent in our outcome-based approach to monetary policy while remaining attentive to the evolution of the data and prepared to adjust as needed.
Rationale: Lael Brainard emphasizes the temporary nature of current inflationary pressures and the importance of remaining steady in monetary policy, which suggests a cautious approach to tightening policy. Her focus on not prematurely tightening policy indicates a somewhat dovish stance, likely leading to a hold on rates.
description: Remarks (via webcast) by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Economic Club of New York, New York, New York, 1 June 2021.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Patience and progress as the economy reopens and recovers
Key quote: Remaining patient through the transitory surge associated with reopening will help ensure that the underlying economic momentum that will be needed to reach our goals as some current tailwinds shift to headwinds is not curtailed by a premature tightening of financial conditions.
Rationale: Lael Brainard emphasizes patience and notes that, while the outlook is bright, uncertainties and risks remain. She focuses on the transitory nature of current inflationary pressures and suggests that a premature tightening of financial conditions should be avoided, indicating a somewhat dovish stance.
description: Remarks (via webcast) by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at "The Road to Recovery and What's Next", a virtual conference sponsored by the Society for Advancing Business Editing and Writing, 11 May 2021.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Remaining patient as the outlook brightens
Key quote: By focusing on eliminating shortfalls from maximum employment rather than deviations in either direction and on the achievement of inflation that averages 2 percent over time, monetary policy can take a patient approach rather than a preemptive approach.
Rationale: Lael Brainard emphasizes patience in monetary policy, focusing on actual outcomes over projections, which suggests a more dovish stance. Despite the brighter outlook, she highlights that employment and inflation are still below target, indicating a preference to maintain current accommodative policies.
description: Remarks (via webcast) by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the National Association for Business Economics Virtual 37th Annual Economic Policy Conference, Washington DC, 23 March 2021.

author: Lael Brainard
title: US economic outlook and monetary policy - an update
Key quote: Today the economy remains far from our goals in terms of both employment and inflation, and it will take some time to achieve substantial further progress.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for continued accommodative monetary policy given the economy is far from achieving the employment and inflation goals. There is patience for allowing inflation to moderately rise above 2% before considering interest rate hikes, thereby suggesting a preference to hold rates in the near term unless inflationary pressures become persistent.
description: Speech (via webcast) by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the C. Peter McColough Series on International Economics, Council on Foreign Relations, New York City, 2 March 2021.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Some preliminary financial stability lessons from the COVID-19 shock
Key quote: The COVID shock subjected the financial system to an acute stress that necessitated emergency interventions on a massive scale by financial authorities around the world.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes financial stability and reforms needed to enhance the resilience of financial systems rather than advocating for immediate monetary policy changes such as rate rises. This suggests a somewhat dovish stance, focusing on financial stability rather than aggressive policy tightening.
description: Remarks by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the 2021 Annual Washington Conference Institute of International Bankers (via webcast), 1 March 2021.

author: Lael Brainard
title: How should we think about full employment in the Federal Reserve's dual mandate?
Key quote: Monetary policy will continue to provide support by keeping borrowing costs for households and businesses low.
Rationale: Lael Brainard's speech emphasizes the need to focus on full employment and highlights the current shortfall in employment relative to pre-pandemic levels. She stresses that monetary policy will continue to provide support, indicating a dovish stance focused on maintaining low rates and supporting economic recovery.
description: Speech (via webcast) by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the the Ec10, Principles of Economics, Lecture, Faculty of Arts and Sciences, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts (via webcast), 24 February 2021.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Full Employment in the New Monetary Policy Framework
Key quote: The economy is far away from our goals in terms of both employment and inflation, and even under an optimistic outlook, it will take time to achieve substantial further progress.
Rationale: Lael Brainard emphasizes the Federal Reserve's commitment to maintaining accommodative monetary policy until substantial progress is made towards full employment and higher inflation, suggesting a dovish stance. Given the economic challenges outlined in the speech, she is likely to support holding rates to foster recovery.
description: Remarks (via webcast) by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Inaugural Mike McCracken Lecture on Full Employment Sponsored by the Canadian Association for Business Economics, 13 January 2021.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Modernising and strengthening CRA regulations - a conversation with the Chicago Community Trust
Key quote: The Federal Reserve is committed to providing sustained accommodation through its forward rate guidance and continued asset purchases to achieve our maximum employment and 2 percent average inflation goals.
Rationale: The emphasis on a need for continued support, both fiscal and monetary, and the commitment to providing sustained accommodation suggests a dovish stance. With concerns over a K-shaped recovery and disproportionate impact on vulnerable communities, it's likely that the current accommodative policies will be maintained.
description: Speech by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Chicago Community Trust, Chicago, 1 December 2020.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Achieving a broad-based and inclusive recovery
Key quote: The Federal Reserve is committed to providing sustained accommodation to achieve a broad-based recovery.
Rationale: Lael Brainard emphasizes the necessity of sustained accommodative monetary policy and additional fiscal support to achieve an inclusive recovery, highlighting a cautious approach given the uneven economic landscape. Her focus on monetary accommodation suggests a dovish stance, yet without immediate pressures to further reduce rates given current low levels.
description: Speech by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the "Post-COVID-Policy Challenges for the Global Economy" Society of Professional Economists Annual Online Conference (via webcast), 21 October 2020.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Bringing the statement on longer-run goals and monetary policy strategy into alignment with longer-run changes in the economy
Key quote: With the recovery likely to face COVID-19-related headwinds for some time, in coming months, it will be important for monetary policy to pivot from stabilization to accommodation.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for monetary policy accommodation, acknowledges risks related to the COVID-19 pandemic, and suggests a strategy that allows for inflation to temporarily exceed targets to support full employment. This suggests a dovish stance aimed at providing support to the economy, making a rate cut unlikely but consistent with maintaining very low rates.
description: Speech (via webcast) by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at  "How the Fed Will Respond to the COVID-19 Recession in an Era of Low Rates and Low Inflation", an event hosted by the Hutchins Center on Fiscal and Monetary Policy at the Brookings Institution, Washington DC, 1 September 2020.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Navigating monetary policy through the fog of COVID
Key quote: Looking ahead, it likely will be appropriate to shift the focus of monetary policy from stabilization to accommodation by supporting a full recovery in employment and a sustained return of inflation to its 2 percent objective.
Rationale: Lael Brainard's speech emphasizes the need for continued accommodation and support for the economy with risks being predominantly on the downside. She acknowledges the slow recovery and the necessity of maintaining lower policy rates, as well as a sustained commitment to accommodation, which are dovish stances.
description: Speech (via webcast) by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Perspectives on the Pandemic Webinar Series, hosted by the National Association for Business Economics, Washington DC, 14 July 2020.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Introductory remarks for the Fed Listens panel on the COVID-19 pandemic
Key quote: It is important to use the full range of tools to support the economy.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the challenges and hardships caused by the COVID-19 pandemic and mentions the need for the Federal Reserve's tools to provide stability and support recovery. This indicates a dovish stance aimed at supporting the economy during a crisis, hence a likelihood for rates to remain on hold given the already low policy rate.
description: Introductory remarks (via webcast) by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at "A Fed Listens Event: How Is COVID-19 Affecting Your Community?", sponsored by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, Washington DC, 21 May 2020.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Monetary policy strategies and tools when inflation and interest rates are low
Key quote: Today's low-inflation, low interest rate environment requires not only new recession-fighting tools but also a new strategy to address the persistent undershooting of the inflation target-and the risk to inflation expectations-well before a downturn.
Rationale: Lael Brainard discusses the need for a new strategy with broader tools, suggesting potential future accommodation due to low inflation and interest rates. While she emphasizes proactive use of a broader toolkit and a focus on achieving inflation targets, the speech leans towards maintaining supportive monetary conditions to avoid downward spirals. However, given the current state, an interest rate cut is not indicated at this time.
description: Speech by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the 2020 US Monetary Policy Forum, sponsored by the Initiative on Global Markets at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, New York City, 21 February 2020.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Federal Reserve review of monetary policy strategy, tools, and communications - some preliminary views
Key quote: The baseline is for continued moderate expansion, a strong labor market, and inflation moving gradually to our symmetric 2 percent objective.
Rationale: Lael Brainard's speech emphasizes a cautious approach to policy changes, highlighting the need to ensure inflation averages 2 percent over time and underscoring the use of tools like yield curve control to provide accommodation. This suggests a dovish stance with a likelihood to hold interest rates.
description: Speech by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Presentation of the 2019 William F. Butler Award, New York Association for Business Economics, New York City, 26 November 2019.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Perspectives on the economy from Scranton
Key quote: Taking into account the downside risks at a time when inflation is on the soft side would argue for softening the expected path of monetary policy according to basic principles of risk management.
Rationale: The speech highlights current downside risks and soft inflation, suggesting a need to soften monetary policy, which implies a dovish stance leaning towards a rate cut.
description: Speech by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Community Bankers Roundtable, Scranton, Pennsylvania, 11 July 2019.

author: Lael Brainard
title: "Fed Listens" in Cincinnati- how does monetary policy affect your community?
Key quote: Basic principles of risk management in a low neutral rate environment with compressed conventional policy space would argue for softening the expected path of policy when risks shift to the downside.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges solid economic conditions but highlights significant downside risks and the importance of sustaining economic momentum, suggesting a willingness to consider lowering rates if necessary.
description: Speech by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Policy Summit 2019 "Connecting People and Places to Opportunity", Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, Cincinnati, Ohio, 21 June 2019.

author: Lael Brainard
title: The disconnect between inflation and employment in the new normal
Key quote: In today's new normal, it is important to achieve inflation and inflation expectations around our 2 percent target on a sustained basis while guarding against financial imbalances through active use of countercyclical tools.
Rationale: Lael Brainard emphasizes the low responsiveness of inflation to labor market conditions and suggests proceeding cautiously, hinting at a risk of financial imbalances despite a strong labor market. Her acknowledgment of a lower neutral interest rate and flat Phillips curve suggests a preference to maintain rather than raise rates.
description: Speech by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the National Tax Association 49th Annual Spring Symposium "Certain Uncertainty: Tax Policy in Unsettled Times", Washington DC, 16 May 2019.

author: Lael Brainard
title: "Fed Listens" in Richmond - how does monetary policy affect your community?
Key quote: Low interest rates present a challenge for the traditional ways of conducting monetary policy.
Rationale: The speech discusses the challenges posed by low interest rates and a flat Phillips curve, which suggest a somewhat dovish stance due to the consideration of accommodating policies. Although new strategies are being explored, the emphasis on understanding the 'new normal' indicates a bias towards being cautious with rate changes, likely resulting in a hold decision.
description: Speech by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Richmond Community Listening Session, Richmond, Virginia, 8 May 2019.

author: Lael Brainard
title: Navigating cautiously
Key quote: At a time when the modal outlook appears to have softened a bit, and risks appear more weighted to the downside than the upside, the best way to safeguard the gains we have made on jobs and inflation is to navigate cautiously on rates.
Rationale: Lael Brainard acknowledges the softening of the modal outlook and the greater downside risks, suggesting a cautious approach in monetary policy. Her emphasis on risk management and watchful waiting indicates a somewhat dovish stance, likely leading her to vote to hold rates stable at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Ms Lael Brainard, Member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Julis-Rabinowitz Center for Public Policy and Finance and the Bendheim Center for Finance, Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey, 7 March 2019.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: How long is too long? How high is too high? - managing recent inflation developments within the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) monetary policy framework
Key quote: I think it is clear that we have met the test of substantial further progress toward both our employment and our inflation mandates, and I would support a decision at our November meeting to start reducing these purchases and complete that process by the middle of next year.
Rationale: While Quarles acknowledges high inflation and supports tapering asset purchases, he does not see the FOMC as behind the curve. His focus is on letting the job market recover and being cautious about when to raise rates, suggesting a readiness for action but not imminently advocating for rate hikes.
description: Speech by Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chair for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the 2021 Milken Institute Global Conference "Charting a New Course," Beverly Hills, California, 20 October 2021.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: Parachute pants and central bank money
Key quote: The potential benefits of a Federal Reserve CBDC are unclear. Conversely, a Federal Reserve CBDC could pose significant and concrete risks.
Rationale: The speech focuses on reflecting the potential risks and skepticism around central bank digital currencies while expressing confidence in the existing U.S. payment system. It signals a conservative approach to innovations that might shift financial dynamics.
description: Speech by Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chair for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the 113th Annual Utah Bankers Association Convention, Sun Valley, Idaho, 28 June 2021.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: The economic outlook and monetary policy
Key quote: If my expectations about economic growth, employment, and inflation over the coming months are borne out, however, and especially if they come in stronger than I expect, then, as noted in the minutes of the last FOMC meeting, it will become important for the FOMC to begin discussing our plans to adjust the pace of asset purchases at upcoming meetings.
Rationale: Quarles expresses optimism regarding the economic recovery but indicates a willingness to adjust asset purchases should inflation and growth surpass expectations. He acknowledges current inflation as temporary but notes risks to inflation on the upside, suggesting a somewhat hawkish stance. Despite this, the focus on holding rates until substantial progress is seen in employment and inflation forecasts supports holding rates steady in the near term.
description: Speech by Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chair for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Hutchins Center on Fiscal and Monetary Policy, The Brookings Institution, Washington DC, (via webcast), 26 May 2021.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: What happened? What have we learned from it? Lessons from COVID-19 stress on the financial system
Key quote: I believe it can tell us a lot about what is working and what aspects of our framework may need strengthening.
Rationale: The speech reflects recognition of the significant challenges posed by the COVID pandemic and highlights various supportive measures taken by the Federal Reserve to ensure liquidity and stability. It acknowledges the unprecedented situation and discusses the accommodative stance taken by the Fed, suggesting a somewhat dovish tone. However, the focus is on maintaining stability rather than indicating an immediate need for further rate cuts, hence a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Speech (via webcast) by Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chairman for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Institute of International Finance, Washington DC, 15 October 2020.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: The importance of transparency, accountability and fairness in regulation
Key quote: Therefore, at the September Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, I voted in favor of the new and clearer forward guidance for monetary policy because it will provide additional support for the recovery.
Rationale: Quarles acknowledges the economic improvement but highlights significant ongoing challenges, such as the depressed labor market and low inflation, supporting his support for the existing forward guidance and monetary policy. His focus on maintaining support for recovery suggests a dovish stance, though not entirely without some optimism about the recovery.
description: Speech (via webcast) by Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chairman for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Hoover Institution, Stanford, 14 October 2020.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: Optimism in the time of COVID
Key quote: In the near term, with both employment and inflation significantly short of the FOMC's economic goals, the prescription is for a sustained aggressive use of monetary policy to support the economy.
Rationale: Quarles emphasizes the need for aggressive monetary policy support due to the economic impacts of COVID-19, which suggests a dovish stance. The recognition of downside risks and need for vigilance indicates a likelihood to hold rates, as the situation is still being assessed.
description: Speech (via webcast) Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chairman for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the 2020 Virtual DC Summit, Institute of International Bankers, Washington, DC, 23 September 2020.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: Global in life and orderly in death - post-crisis reforms and the too-big-to-fail question
Key quote: The policy response by central banks and governments to this liquidity shock was rapid and decisive.
Rationale: The speech mainly focuses on financial stability and how banks are resilient due to post-crisis reforms. It acknowledges the uncertainty and challenges from COVID-19 but highlights the preparedness and coordination in the financial system. The speaker does not suggest any immediate need to change the policy rate, so 'Hold' is the most likely stance.
description: Speech (via webcast) by Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chairman for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Exchequer Club, Washington DC, 7 July 2020.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: The adaptability of stress testing
Key quote: Our use of the sensitivity analysis is an acknowledgement that the path ahead is unusually uncertain, but that the work of verifying the resiliency of banks must continue, to aid the recovery by bolstering public confidence in the financial system.
Rationale: The speech focuses on explaining the adaptability of stress testing during the COVID-19 pandemic, highlighting the strength of banks and the importance of stress tests in maintaining financial stability. Quarles discusses the flexibility of the stress test process but does not explicitly advocate for changing interest rates, indicating a neutral stance. Given the inherent uncertainty and the emphasis on maintaining current capital policies, the speaker is likely to advocate for holding the policy rate steady.
description: Speech Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chairman for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at Women in Housing and Finance, Washington DC, 19 June 2020.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: Supervision and regulation report
Key quote: More may be required of us before the current crisis ends.
Rationale: Randal K. Quarles' speech reflects a commitment to supporting the economy through regulatory and supervisory measures, with a strong emphasis on maintaining credit flow and easing financial system pressure. Given the exceptional economic hardship described in the speech and the already low policy rate, further rate cuts seem unlikely, thus the most probable action is to hold rates steady.
description: Testimony of Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chairman for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, before the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs, US Senate, Washington DC, 12 May 2020.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: The economic outlook, monetary policy and the demand for reserves
Key quote: I view the current stance of monetary policy as appropriate given the economic outlook and relatively muted inflation pressures.
Rationale: Quarles expresses confidence in the current monetary policy stance, viewing it as appropriate given the outlook and low inflation, suggesting a high likelihood of holding rates at the upcoming meeting.
description: Speech by Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chair for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Money Marketeers of New York University, New York City, 6 February 2020.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: Friedrich Hayek and the price system
Key quote: Overall, with these policy adjustments, I believe that the economy will remain in a good place, with the labor market remaining strong and inflation staying close to our 2 percent objective.
Rationale: Randal K. Quarles acknowledges both positive and negative aspects of the economy, highlighting strong employment but also concerns about weak global growth and investment. Given the recent rate cut and his optimistic view that policy is currently appropriate, a neutral stance is suggested, which aligns with a hold on interest rates.
description: Speech by Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chair for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at "The Road to Serfdom at 75: The Future of Classical Liberalism and the Free Market", Ninth Annual Conference of the William F. Buckley, Jr., Program at Yale, New Haven, Connecticut, 1 November 2019.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: Refining the Stress Capital Buffer
Key quote: Our goals remain to simplify our capital framework while maintaining the overall amount of capital in the U.S. banking system.
Rationale: The speech focuses on maintaining a high level of loss-absorbing capacity and refining regulations, which are somewhat hawkish stances. However, there's also an emphasis on simplification and maintaining current capital levels, suggesting a more balanced position leading to a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Speech by Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chair for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the Program on International Financial Systems Conference, Frankfurt am Main, 5 September 2019.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: Monetary policy and financial stability
Key quote: A general consensus has emerged that monetary policy should be guided primarily by the outlook for unemployment and inflation and not by the state of financial vulnerabilities.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes a balanced approach to monetary policy, prioritizing the targets of employment and inflation over adjusting for financial vulnerabilities. This suggests a neutral stance with a likelihood of holding rates steady.
description: Speech by Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chair for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at "Developments in Empirical Macroeconomics", a research conference sponsored by the Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Washington DC, 30 May 2019.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: Frameworks for the Countercyclical Capital Buffer
Key quote: In regard to policy, I am very comfortable remaining patient at this point and monitoring the incoming data.
Rationale: The speaker emphasizes a patient and data-dependent approach, indicating potential for future rate increases but not committing to immediate action, consistent with a neutral stance.
description: Speech by Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chairman for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the "Strategic Approaches to the Fed's Balance Sheet and Communications" Spring 2019 Meeting of the Manhattan Institute's Shadow Open Market Committee, New York City, 29 March 2019.

author: Randal K Quarles
title: The future of the Federal Reserve's balance sheet
Key quote: Finally, in assessing our balance sheet policy, it is important to point out that the Fed remains entirely focused on meeting its statutory dual-mandate objectives of maximum employment and price stability.
Rationale: The speech indicates a cautious approach towards balance sheet normalization, suggesting readiness to adjust if it impacts dual-mandate goals. The emphasis on ample reserves hints at a slightly dovish stance, but maintaining interest rates suggests a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Speech by Mr Randal K Quarles, Vice Chairman for Supervision of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, at the 2019 US Monetary Policy Forum, sponsored by the Initiative on Global Markets at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, New York City, 22 February 2019.
